Haueing made these observations, I first computed from them the 
refractive power of that glasse, and found it measured by the ratio of 
the sines 20 to 31 And then by that ratio I computed the refractions 
of two Rays, flowing from opposite parts of the Sun’s discus so 
as to differ 31 in their obliquity of incidence and found yt ye Emergent 
Rays should have comprehended an Angle of about 31 as they did 
before they were incident 
But because this computac[i]on was founded on the Hypothesis of 
the proportionalty of the sines of incidence and refractions which 
though by my own experience I could not imagine to be soe erroneous 
as to make that Angle but 31 which in reality was 2 deg. 49 yet 
my curiosity caused me againe to take my Prisme And haueing placed it 
at my window as before, I observed yt by turning it a little about it 
Axis to & fro, so as to vary its obliquity to ye light more then an Angle 
of 4 or 5 deg. the colours were not there by Sincibly translated from their 
place on the wall and consiquently by that variation of incidence 
the quantity of refraction was not sensibly varied. By this experim[en]t 
therefore, as well as by the former computac[i]on it was evident that the 
differance of the incidence of Rays, flowing from divers parts of the 
Sun could not make them after decussation diverge at a Sensible greater 
Angle then that at which they before converged which being at most 
but about 31 or 32 minuts there stile remained some other cause to 
be found out, from whence it could be 2 deg 49
Then I began to Suspect whether the Rays after their trajection 
through the Prisme, did not move in curved lines and according to their 
more or less curvity tend to divers parts of the wall, And it increased 
my Suspition, when I remembred I had often seen a Tennis ball 
struck with an oblique Racket, describe such a curve line For a circular 
as well as a progressive motion being comunicated to it by yt stroake,
its parts on that side where the motions conspire, must presse and 
beat the contiguous Aire more violent then on the other, and their 
excite a reluctancy and reaction of the Aire proportionably greater: 
And for the same reason if the Rays of light should possibly be globular 
bodies and by their oblique passage out of one medium into another 
acquire a circulating motion, they out to feel the greater resistance from 
the ambient AEther, on that side where the motion conspire and thence 
be continually bowed to the other  But notwithstanding these plau=
sable grounds of suspition when I came to examine it I could observe 
noe such curvity in them And besids (wch was enough for my purpose) I 
observed that the difference twixt the lenght of the Image and 
diameter of the <s>w<\s>hole through which the light was transmitted was 
proportionable to their distance
